title: Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi: the Iraqi academic who emerged from obscurity to impose a brutal terrorist rule
text:
The man that stood at the helm of the world’s most feared terrorist organisation in modern times carefully controlled a fractious mix of domestic jihadists and disillusioned foreign extremists, creating an army that would for a time impose its brutal rule over eight million people.

Though barely seen in public, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, who died in a US raid overnight on Saturday, established a de facto terrorist state that held territory across two countries.

The group generated hundreds of millions of dollars, created a complex administrative structure and had a media presence so sophisticated that it attracted fighters from all over the world. An Iraqi national, Baghdadi was the son of a Muslim preacher.

He was an academic and en route to a PhD when his sights turned to Salafi jihadism in 2003 as US troops invaded. It would be less than a decade before he became known for beheadings, bombings and unfolding mass terror.

Having joined a local resistance movement during the invasion, Baghdadi was detained by US forces at Camp Bucca in 2004. Considered a low-level threat by US forces, he was released after ten months.

Baghdadi gravitated towards al-Qaeda in Iraq. In 2006, when its leader Ayman al-Zawahiri was killed in a US airstrike, the group rebranded itself as the Islamic State of Iraq.
